If false, the filter includes only those packets that match the VLANIDCheck entry, if specified. If true, the filter includes all packets except those that match the VLANIDCheck entry, if specified.

DSCP with which to mark the outer IP header for traffic that is associated with the interface criterion. Automatic DSCP marking behavior is a local matter to the device, possibly influenced by other Broadband Forum standards that it supports. A value of -1 indicates copy from the upstream packet. A value of -2 indicates automatic marking of DSCP.

This object contains parameters associated with the Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) Tunnel ({{bibref|RFC2784}}) with Key and Sequence Number extensions ({{bibref|RFC2890}}). This object also provides a means to treat packets that are encapsulated within a GRE Tunnel by using a set of {{object|Filter}} objects to determine the treatment of the packet.
The number of entries in the Tunnel table.
The number of entries in the Filter table.

GRE Tunnel table, models the GRE Tunnel instance and represents the entry point and exit point of the tunnel in relation to the WAN interface. A {{object}} object has one or more {{object|Interface}} objects that further define the sessions or flows within the tunnel.
Enables or disables the tunnel.
The current operational state of the tunnel.
A non-volatile handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for future reference.

The Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) or IP address of the remote GRE tunnel endpoint. If more than one name/address is supplied, they will be tried in turn, i.e. they are in decreasing order of precedence.
The mechanism used to keep the tunnel from timing out at the {{param|ConnectedRemoteEndpoint}}.
The tunnel keepalive timeout in {{units}}.
Number of KeepAlive messages unacknowledged by the {{param|ConnectedRemoteEndpoint}} before the {{object}} is perceived failed.
The protocol used for the delivery header.

If the specified entries in the {{object|#.Filter}} table do not match this {{object}} object or an instance of the {{object|Interface}} object for this {{object}} object, then the value of this parameter is applied to the delivery header of the packets in this {{object}}.
The Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) name or IP address of the connected remote GRE tunnel endpoint.
The number of entries in the Interface table.

Statistics for this GRE tunnel, i.e. all traffic that has passed through the tunnel. The device MUST reset the tunnel's Stats parameters (unless otherwise stated in individual object or parameter descriptions) either when the tunnel becomes operationally down due to a previous administrative down (i.e., Status parameter transitions to a disabled state after the tunnel has been disabled) or when the tunnel becomes administratively up (i.e. the Enable parameter transitioned from {{false}} to {{true}}).
The total number of KeepAlive messages sent out the tunnel.
The total number of KeepAlive messages received by the tunnel.
The total number of bytes sent by the tunnel.
The total number of bytes received by the tunnel.
The total number of packets sent by the tunnel.
The total number of packets received by the tunnel.
The total number of packets discarded by the tunnel due to any error. This can include packets dropped due to a lack of transmit buffers.
The total number of packets received by the tunnel that contained errors preventing them from being delivered to a higher-layer protocol.

GRE Interface table (a stackable interface object as described in {{bibref|TR-181i2|Section 4.2}}). The {{object}} object models the GRE Header as defined in {{bibref|RFC7348}} for the transport of L2 frames across over GRE. The {{object}} object provides a way to discriminate how multiple LAN segments are encapsulated within the GRE Tunnel. In addition the {{object}} object represents the entry point and exit point of the tunnel in relation to the LAN interface.
Enables or disables the interface. This parameter is based on ''ifAdminStatus'' from {{bibref|RFC2863}}.

The current operational state of the interface (see {{bibref|TR-181i2|Section 4.2.2}}). {{enum}} When {{param|Enable}} is {{false}} then {{param}} SHOULD normally be {{enum|Down}} (or {{enum|NotPresent}} or {{enum|Error}} if there is a fault condition on the interface). When {{param|Enable}} is changed to {{true}} then {{param}} SHOULD change to {{enum|Up}} if and only if the interface is able to transmit and receive network traffic; it SHOULD change to {{enum|Dormant}} if and only if the interface is operable but is waiting for external actions before it can transmit and receive network traffic (and subsequently change to {{enum|Up}} if still operable when the expected actions have completed); it SHOULD change to {{enum|LowerLayerDown}} if and only if the interface is prevented from entering the {{enum|Up}} state because one or more of the interfaces beneath it is down; it SHOULD remain in the {{enum|Error}} state if there is an error or other fault condition detected on the interface; it SHOULD remain in the {{enum|NotPresent}} state if the interface has missing (typically hardware) components; it SHOULD change to {{enum|Unknown}} if the state of the interface can not be determined for some reason. This parameter is based on ''ifOperStatus'' from {{bibref|RFC2863}}.
A non-volatile handle used to reference this instance. Alias provides a mechanism for an ACS to label this instance for future reference.
The textual name of the interface as assigned by the CPE.
The accumulated time in seconds since the interface entered its current operational state.
A timestamp, in seconds, of the last status change. Used to calculate the TR181 LastChange value.
{{list}} {{reference|an interface object that is stacked immediately below this interface object}} See {{bibref|TR-181i2|Section 4.2.1}}.
The Protocol ID assigned to this {{object}}. The Protocol Id is the EtherType value used to identify the encapsulated payload. When set to {{null}} the CPE determines the Protocol Id.
When {{true}}, includes the "Checksum" field in the GRE header as defined in {{bibref|RFC2784}}.
The method used to generate the Key Identifier extension as defined in.{{bibref|RFC2890}}.

When the value of {{param|KeyIdentifierGenerationPolicy}} is {{enum|Provisioned|KeyIdentifierGenerationPolicy}} this {{param}} parameter is used to identify an individual traffic flow within a GRE tunnel, as defined in {{bibref|RFC2890}}.
When {{true}}, includes the "SequenceNumber" field in the GRE header as defined in {{bibref|RFC2890}}
Indicates if this GRE Tunnel Interface is a Bridged service.

Statistics for this GRE tunnel interface, i.e. all traffic that has passed through the interface. The device MUST reset the interface's Stats parameters (unless otherwise stated in individual object or parameter descriptions) either when the interface becomes operationally down due to a previous administrative down (i.e., the interface's Status parameter transitions to a down state after the interface has been disabled) or when the interface becomes administratively up (i.e. the Enable parameter transitioned from {{false}} to {{true}}).
The total number of bytes sent by this interface.
The total number of bytes received by this interface.
The total number of packets sent by this interface.
The total number of {{units}} received by this interface.
The total number of packets discarded by this interface due to any error. This can include packets dropped due to a lack of transmit buffers.
The total number of packets received by this interface that contained errors preventing them from being delivered to a higher-layer protocol.
The total number of packets received by the tunnel interface that are discarded because of Checksum errors.
The total number of packets received by the tunnel interface that are discarded because of Sequence Number errors.

This objects contains configuration parameters for the BAS-D app.
When enable is true, bas-d will try to connect to the bas-p portal if the portal address is configured.

Indicates the status of this application. Enumeration of: Idle (this instance is in an Idle state and not running)
Active (this instance is currently running) Error_Misconfigured (this instance has a necessary configuration value that is undefined or invalid.) Error (this instance has a locally defined error condition.)
The time when status of this application changes.
A string indicating the reason of the status change.
When true, bas-d is in the restarting process. This is used internally. When restart is requested, this flag needs to be set. Otherwise, it should be cleared.

The host name or IP address of the BAS Portal. To disable SSL, as defined in RFC 3986 [15], the <scheme-specific-partgt; composes of tcp://the IP address or hostname of the BAS-P followed by ':' and the port number of 1883. Setting this parameter is required if Bas-d is Enabled.
A unique ID identifying this device (e.g. its MAC address).

Configures the first session retry wait interval, in seconds. A value of 5 corresponds to the default behavior. Other values in the retry pattern MUST be calculated using this value as a starting point.

Configures the retry interval multiplier. This value is expressed in units of 0.001. Hence the values of the multiplier range are between 1.000 and 65.535. A value of 2000 corresponds to the default behavior. Other values in the retry pattern MUST be calculated using this value as a starting point.
This paramter sets basd application's debug level. Debug value 0 is print all debug messages, 1 debugTraceLevel2, 2 debugTraceLevel1, 3 debug, 4 warning, 5 error, 6 disable
Username used to authenticate the MQTT BAS when making a connection to the MQTT broker. It is an optional parameter.
Password used to authenticate the MQTT BAS when making a connection to the MQTT broker. It is an optional parameter.
The duration in seconds for KeepAliveInterval (MQTT) in bas daemon.
The number of entries status entries in the anomaly history table.
The maximum number of entries status entries in the history table. The entries will be purged (FIFO) to stay until the MaxHistoryNumberOfEntries.

BAS Anomaly History Table. The history of when basd exits due to an anomaly and not an admisntrative restart or disable, for example. The system utilizes a process' exit code to detect anomaly. If a process catches the signal, handles it and exits gracefully, the management system will not be able to detect an anomaly.

Indicates the status of this application. Enumeration of: Idle (this instance is in an Idle state and not running)
Active (this instance is currently running) Error_Misconfigured (this instance has a necessary configuration value that is undefined or invalid.) Error (this instance has a locally defined error condition.)
The time when status of this application changes.
A string indicating the reason of the status change.
BAS Clients Table.
Name of this BAS client.
When set to true, clients to basd to subscribe services to it.

Indicates the status of this application. Enumeration of: Idle (this instance is in an Idle state and not running)
Active (this instance is currently running) Error_Misconfigured (this instance has a necessary configuration value that is undefined or invalid.) Error (this instance has a locally defined error condition.)
The time when status of this application changes.
A string indicating the reason of the status change.
When true, client is in the restarting process. When a restart is desired, this flag is set to true. Otherwise, it should be cleared. This is used internally.
When true, this client has been statically added to the table by the management system when the feature is enabled in the firmware.
For static client, this field can be empty. This is the executable to start the client if it is a dynamic client.

This paramter can optionally be set to be used as argument to the client start executable. For example, to include debug level for the client, this parameter can have value of -d 0. Debug value 0 is print all debug messages, 1 debugTraceLevel2, 2 debugTraceLevel1, 3 debug, 4 warning, 5 error, 6 disable
The number of entries status entries in the history table.
The maximum number of entries status entries in the history table. The entries will be purged (FIFO) to stay until the MaxHistoryNumberOfEntries.

BAS Clients History Table. BAS Anomaly History Table. The history of when the client exits due to an anomaly and not an admisntrative restart or disable, for example. The system utilizes a process' exit code to detect anomaly. If a process catches the signal, handles it and exits gracefully, the management system will not be able to detect an anomaly.

Indicates the status of this application. Enumeration of: Idle (this instance is in an Idle state and not running)
Active (this instance is currently running) Error_Misconfigured (this instance has a necessary configuration value that is undefined or invalid.) Error (this instance has a locally defined error condition.)
The time when status of this application changes.
A string indicating the reason of the status change.

This value is the full path name of a row in the ExecEnv table if container is associated with the execution environment. Not all container will have an association with an execution environment, in which case, this value will be an empty string.
This value is the full path of a row in a table that this container reference to. For example, it can be referenced to a table in ExecutionUnit table. Or it can be referenced to a table of images.
This object contains container state information.
